_prev_prog_3.Description: Silane Iso Module Transfill- This process is the transfilling (cascade and compression) from (1) ISO module into other containers and storage  of up to  (8) full 20' or 40'  ISO modules . The facility has developed prevention program elements based on the Federal EPA Accidental release Prevention Plan and OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation.  In addition, the facility implements the American Chemistry Council Responsible Care codes of management practice and complies with all local and state specific regulatory requirements.

_prev_prog_3.Description: HCl Storage at West II- This process includes the storage only of up to (17) full hydrogen chloride tube trailers/ISO units (up to 21,000 lbs per unit). The facility has developed prevention program elements based on the Federal EPA Accidental release Prevention Plan and OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation.  In addition, the facility implements the American Chemistry Council Responsible Care codes of management practice and complies with all local and state specific regulatory requirements.

_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Pressure vessel inspection required by State of Pennsylvania
_prev_prog_3.Description: Aqueous Ammonia Storage- This process includes the generation, storage and off-loading of <30% Aqua Ammonia. The solution is generated from the venting of ammonia from the process plant. Increased production has resulted in the need to increase capacity. The facility has developed prevention program elements based on the Federal EPA Accidental release Prevention Plan and OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation.  In addition, the facility implements the American Chemistry Council Responsible Care codes of management practice and complies with all local and state specific regulatory requirements.
Phosphine Storage at Shipping- This process includes the storage and handling of phosphine cylinders.

_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: Fixed and portable water cannons (water spray)
_prev_prog_3.Description: Ammonia Unloading, Storage, Purification and Distribution- This process includes the unloading of ammonia from tank trucks into a storage tank, and the distribution of NH3 to three nitrogen trifluoride plants and to the ammonia purification plant for filling compressed gas containers. The facility has developed prevention program elements based on the Federal EPA Accidental release Prevention Plan and OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation.  In addition, the facility implements the American Chemistry Council Responsible Care codes of management practice and complies with all local and state specific regulatory requirements.

Fluorine Manufacturing and Distrbution- This process includes the manufacture of fluorine, its storage in hydril tubes, and the distribution of F2 to other processes and to cylinder and tube trailer filling, either as pure gas or in mixtures with nitrogen or helium. The facility has developed prevention program elements based on the Federal EPA Accidental release Prevention Plan and OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation.  In addition, the facility implements the American Chemistry Council Responsible Care codes of management practice and complies with all local and state specific regulatory requirements.

HF Storage and Distribution- This process includes the unloading of HF directly from railcars inside a totally enclosed containment building.  The HF is distributed to the F2 plants as a raw material and to the liquid fill area for filling compressed gas containers. The facility has developed prevention program elements based on the Federal EPA Accidental release Prevention Plan and OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation.  In addition, the facility implements the American Chemistry Council Responsible Care codes of management practice and complies with all local and state specific regulatory requirements.

The facility has developed prevention program elements based on the Federal EPA Accidental release Prevention Plan and OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation.  In addition, the facility implements the American Chemistry Council Responsible Care codes of management practice and complies with all local and state specific regulatory requirements.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary





Versum Materials US, LLC.

Hometown Electronics Specialty Gases Facility



1.  Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies:



It is our policy to adhere to all applicable Federal and state rules and regulations.  Versum Materials manages the safety of the regulated processes by means of operating procedures, equipment testing and inspections, safety devices (e.g., alarms, shutdowns, instrumentation, relief devices) inherent in the design of this facility and other controls and systems designed to prevent accidental releases of hazardous chemicals.  Safe work practices and training of our personnel supplement the inherent safe design of the plant.



Our emergency response program is based upon the OSHAA HAZWOPER regulation.  The emergency response plan includes procedures for the notification of the local fire authority and Hazardous Materials unit so that appropriate measures can be taken by local emergency responders to control accidental releases.



2.  The stationary source and regulated substances handled:



The primary purpose of this facility is the production of specialty and electronic gases and chemicals.  A majority of these gases are derived from fluorine, which is generated at the site in electrolytic cells by electrical decomposition of hydrogen fluoride.  Hydrogen is generated as a by-product, which is vented in small amounts to the atmosphere.  The electrolysis takes place in a cell containing hydrogen fluoride with dissolved potassium bifluoride.  The majority of the fluorine is cooled by liquid nitrogen to remove residual hydrogen fluoride and potassium fluoride carried over from the electrolytic cells.  After these impurities are removed, the gas is compressed for distribution to the various fluorine users throughout the facility.



The hydrogen fluoride is brought on site by railcar that is placed inside a totally enclosed containment building for processing.  The hydrogen fluoride is then fed directl

y from the railcar to the fluorine plant or pumped into cylinders, which are stored and maintained on site for shipment to customers.  Additional railcars are stored outside of the building due to the increasing demand for the material.



This facility also re-packages anhydrous hydrogen chloride.  The hydrogen chloride is brought on site by railcar.  From the railcar, it is transferred through a series of heat exchangers and pumps to the tube trailers and cylinders.  Also, tube trailers and cylinder storage of hydrogen chloride are maintained.



Anhydrous ammonia is brought on site by tank truck and pumped into a stationary storage tank.  It is used as a raw material in the production of nitrogen trifluoride (NF3).  NF3 is made by introducing fluorine gas into ammonium bifluoride.  Ammonia is transferred under its own storage tank pressure, vaporized, and fed to the system to control the hydrogen fluoride concentration in the product, and to replenish the ammonium bifluoride.  Anhydrous ammonia is also fed to a purification plant, where moisture is removed before it is re-packaged into other bulk containers. The packaged bulk containers are stored adjacent to the purification plant.



Aqueous ammonia is generated from off gas in the ammonia production facility.





Hydrogen selenide is produced by the reduction/hydrogenation of pure (elemental) Selenium. The reaction takes place in a reactor and is carried out with an excess of hydrogen.  The resulting H2Se is removed from the gas stream by liquefaction into collectors.  From here, it is transferred into product cylinders, which are stored in our shipping/receiving area.



Arsine cylinders and chlorine containers are filled at other locations and are only stored in our shipping/receiving area.  Cylinders of boron trichloride which contain residual product are received from other sites and re-packaged into A-5 containers for resale or disposal.



Phosphine cylinders are are filled at other locations and brough

t to the site where the package external valve is cleaned and the cylinders stored in our shipping/receiving area. 



This resubmittal is the result of current and future increases in demand for our products, most notable fluorine, ammonia, silane and hydrogen chloride. Production is expected to rise and additional tube trailers and Iso-Modules are being added to the fleet. The regulated substances handled at this facility are fluorine, hydrogen fluoride, anhydrous hydrogen chloride, anhydrous ammonia, aqua ammonia, arsine, boron trichloride, hydrogen selenide, chlorine, phosphine,  and silane.  Trichlorosilane has been removed from this submittal as the facility had been a return point for containers as the company exited the business in the United States and the inventory has been reduced to levels below the threshold quantity and not expected to increase.



3.  This update includes the addition of storage locations and the additon of an Aqua ammonia process due to ammonia plant modifications based on anticipated increase in production. 



4.  The general accidental release prevention program and specific prevention steps:



The facility developed prevention program elements based on the Federal EPA Accidental Release Prevention Plan and OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation.  In addition, the facility implements the American Chemistry Council Responsible Care codes of management practice and complies with all local and state

specific regulatory requirements.  This update includes revisions to the prevention programs for all ten processes on site.



5.  Five-year accident history:



This facility came on line in March of 1973.  In the last five years, there have been two accidental releases that meet the requirements under RMP: hydrogen fluoride (one) and fluorine (one).  Each of these incidents resulted in a single injury to operating personnel on site.



6.  The emergency response program:



The facility complies with all EPA, OSHA, and Compre

ssed Gas Association requirements for emergency response. Employees that are members of the on-site emergency response team at the facility will respond to emergencies before initiating emergency response from outside agencies.  



The facility maintains an Emergency Procedure Manual that contains specific procedures for employees to take in the event of an emergency or accidental release. This information also contains the names and numbers of responding outside agencies.  



7.  Planned changes to improve safety:



The facility resolves recommendations from Process Hazards Analysis and Near Miss Incident Investigations, some of which may result in modifications to the plant design and operating procedures.  It also strives toward continuous improvement in regards to EH&S and good engineering practices and design. 



Versum Materials US, LLC. has implemented EH&S Global standards and best practices that often exceed regulatory standards.
